When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation".

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

The government had to act fast.
 After forty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. T

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be give

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidot

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug"

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?

The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely.

If so, when?

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?

The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last ge

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing t

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the f

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.

You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?

 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the steriltiy. No

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?

The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. N

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. Now the people that had tak

The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. Now the people that had taken the drug were sterile

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?

The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. Now the people that had taken the drug were sterile and aging like they had never taken the drug. t

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. Now the people that had taken the drug were sterile and aging like they had never taken the drug. This led to mass

The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. Now the people that had taken the drug were sterile and aging like they had never taken the drug. This led to massive revolts and war. Ev

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. Now the people that had taken the drug were sterile and aging like they had never taken the drug. This led to massive revolts and war. Eventually both t

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?

Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. Now the people that had taken the drug were sterile and aging like they had never taken the drug. This led to massive revolts and war. Eventually both the mortals and immorta

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.

The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. Now the people that had taken the drug were sterile and aging like they had never taken the drug. This led to massive revolts and war. Eventually both the mortals and immortals destroyed each othe

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?

After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. Now the people that had taken the drug were sterile and aging like they had never taken the drug. This led to massive revolts and war. Eventually both the mortals and immortals destroyed each other

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. Now the people that had taken the drug were sterile and aging like they had never taken the drug. This led to massive revolts and war. Eventually both the mortals and immortals destroyed each other and now no huma

The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
 They decided to make and antidote for the "immortality drug" offering people the hope that maybe the sterilization effect could be reversed. Some people were against it completely. They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. Now the people that had taken the drug were sterile and aging like they had never taken the drug. This led to massive revolts and war. Eventually both the mortals and immortals destroyed each other and now no human is left. i

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

They wanted to be immortal and did not want to risk the chance of having their immortality taken away. Others did not want the pressure of being the "last generation and were willing to take the risk. After the first round of antidote was given out people found that there was no reversing the sterility. Now the people that had taken the drug were sterile and aging like they had never taken the drug. This led to massive revolts and war. Eventually both the mortals and immortals destroyed each other and now no human is left. It turns o

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?

Now the people that had taken the drug were sterile and aging like they had never taken the drug. This led to massive revolts and war. Eventually both the mortals and immortals destroyed each other and now no human is left. It turns out, not even immortal

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

It was inevitable. For years, the younger generations thought they had it all no aging, the feeling of youth, banishing the "lost generation" to grow old in their communes and die off so they would not bother the "immortals" Little did they know they would be the "last generation". 
The government had to act fast.
 After sixty years the side effects had been realized. You could not die form old age (you could still die from other things like accidents, murder, etc.), but you become sterile and can no longer reproduce. The people that did not take the drug that died off and the others that were too old to reproduce would be no help at ensuring any more population on the planet. The government had to find a way to keep the population going. Should they genetically produce citizens? How would that work? Would they be considered human? Would they be given the drug? If so, when?
The government decided to do something that would have been considered unthinkable before.
